item.title: Oaths and Treason
item.description: Fp edit: I appreciate you all. I'm sorry that our nation is in the position it is in. I thought we were better than this. I obviously thought wrong. I'm a disabled veteran. My duty was to the Constitution. Not a wannabe dictator who called me a sucker and a loser for choosing selfless service. Now because of him I struggle daily and I'm not too hopeful for the future.

26 Imgur Creator Spotlight: @PilotBuilder did this cool painting of the open sea at night. Check out their other stuff in their posts!
27 Man Tax: Jenson Button
“Human beings, who are almost unique in having the ability to learn from the experience of others, are also remarkable for their apparent disinclination to do so.” - Douglas Adams I try to keep my posts "good vibe zones". So, instead of finding the one thing in here you don't like and commenting only on that, also comment about something you DID like. Balance the negativity. Love you long time. So, I made a discord server. It's a relaxed environment where you can take/donate memes to the cause, play trivia twice a week, chat about lots of topics or about nothing at all. We also have Jack Box game night and are setting up movie night! Very laid back/relaxed vibe. Come hang with us. https://discord.gg/AWFV7FT3RQ I'm also on the imgcat server for updates & fun: https://discord.gg/TpjD37jgJ9 ***Also if you miss abbiistabbii's discord community good news! Here's the new one https://discord.gg/NPStJGgARq - where everyone's reconnecting, shitposting, and hanging out again*** https://ko-fi.com/mememuseumcurator Unable to work and pretty destitute. Feel free to leave me a tip. Those that have, y'all are the bee's knees. You've helped me so much. ***Tag me if you see an artist/creator you like whose work isn't getting seen as much as it should be! Or if you are an artist/creator and want me to post something of yours, DM me!

item.title: Do not suffer alone
item.description: It is deeply perplexing how some can turn their gaze away from the suffering around them, or worse, revel in extinguishing the flickering flames of hope in those already broken. Too often, these individuals seek out the most vulnerable, desperate to stir public scorn against those who have already been cast down by the harshest realities of life. But there was a time, long before our days, when we looked over the fences that divided us not with suspicion or disdain, but with concern and compassion. We made sure our neighbors had enough that no one was left to perish without the barest essentials of life. We stood up, shoulder to shoulder, for the less fortunate. Today, entire communities and the people within them are viewed as blights upon the land, as if poverty itself were a contagion rather than a call for collective humanity. My grandfather gave me a creed that shapes every fiber of my being: “Nothing is worth doing unless it makes life easier or better for someone else.” This principle demands no recognition or applause it is a quiet, unwavering commitment to service. My acts of kindness require no witness, no validation. Helping others is simply what we do when we truly see one another. This life of service is not a burden but a privilege, an expression of love for a world rich with diversity and complexity. Yet, I often retreat from public spaces especially the halls of online discourse because of the venomous malice that too frequently spills from the mouths of many. But I do not hate those who spread hatred; I pity them. How many bear hidden wounds so deep that speaking of them invites mockery or cruelty from those who fancy themselves morally superior? In truth, we are all grappling with our mortality and fragility. No single soul can transform the world alone, but united in purpose, we can cut through society’s decay and breathe life into the hope of a better tomorrow. So, when you next encounter a person in need, pause and look beyond surface judgments. Perhaps you have never known the gnawing ache of true hunger or the terror of uncertain shelter. Maybe you have always had the privilege of warmth on cold nights and the dignity of small comforts. Poverty is not a choice, but a crucible few escape unscathed. Most of us would give everything we have for the chance to uplift another to light their path when all seems lost. remember our shared humanity. act with love not as an obligation but as a radical reclaiming of what it means to be truly human. Together, we can forge a world where no one is left to suffer in silence
item.dc:creator: LedsenPotatis

item.title: Goodbye Kitten
item.description:
My wife & I started dating in early 2014. Before we moved in together, we popped into an adoption day at a pet food store to “look at the cute cats” and left with this little perfect kitten. We called her Millicent McFuckerdoodle II, First of Her Name & Archduchess of Disastermess because we were young & had a weird sense of humour. But in the end we just called her Millie, or Mills.
She *always* looked concerned about everything going on around her.
Unless she looked sleepy - then, she just seemed suspicious.
She had a perfect little snoot.
And she *loved* being upside down.
Or just plain silly
She made friends with some cats. Especially if they couldn’t touch her and she couldn’t smell them.
She did not appreciate being dressed up, even if it made her look cute as a button.
Did I mention she loved being upside down? Belly rubs, too.
Sometimes concern became menace.
When that happened, sometimes you had to pay the belly rub tax.
She was always down to be picked up. She could rest in my arms for an hour if I was so inclined.
She was always curious about what was going on, too.
One time she tried to form a union to get more breakfasts.
When it didn’t work, she demanded belly rubs.
Outside of union organizing, she only tolerated her little brother.
She loved being around us. Snoozing on the backs of our couches while we just hung out.
Did I mention she liked to be a bit silly?
Two years ago, she got diabetes.
No matter how much insulin we threw at it, we were never able to control her sugar. But she did eventually find a decent quality of life.
It took a while, and a lot of dosage adjustment.
But she was able to enjoy life a little bit again.
After a while, though, things deteriorated. For the last two months, despite being on 13 units of insulin a day, she has been *constantly* starving. Every waking moment was spent either begging for food or sleeping next to her bowl. I couldn’t imagine how desperate that feeling must have been. At 13 units of insulin we couldn’t just keep upping the dose. The vet thinks she had a tumour on her pancreas, but a 12 year old cat getting surgery on a major internal organ is a crapshoot.
So today her suffering ended. She had two breakfasts.
And a big plate of every kind of treat under the sun.
And then a vet came to the house and did what needed to be done. She passed with my wife & I stroking her fur, telling her how much we loved her. It was peaceful, and I’m relieved to know she isn’t starving anymore - that she isn’t suffering every minute of every day. I’m gonna miss you, Mills. You were my silly little kitten, no matter how old you got.
item.dc:creator: StevenAlleyn
